Introduction

Scabies is a highly contagious parasitic infestation of the skin caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei (

image 1
), which triggers a delayed type IV hypersensitivity reaction.  Patients classically present with intense pruritus and a characteristic skin rash.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Scabies is caused by female S scabiei mites that burrow into the epidermis.  After burrowing, they lay eggs and excrete feces, triggering a delayed type IV hypersensitivity reaction.  Patients develop intense pruritus and skin inflammation, typically 3-6 weeks after the initial infestation.  During this time, patients with classic scabies carry an average of 10-15 mites.  In contrast, patients with reduced cellular immunity (eg, immunosuppression, HIV) may carry millions of mites on their body.



Scabies occurs worldwide and affects patients of every age.  Transmission occurs primarily through direct, prolonged skin-to-skin contact with a person with scabies infestation.  Therefore, factors that increase the likelihood of prolonged interpersonal contact (eg, crowded living conditions) increase the risk for scabies.



Because mites can survive up to 3 days without a host, transmission can also occur due to contact with contaminated fomites (eg, bedsheets, clothing).  This is more likely to occur if the original host had a large mite burden (thousands to millions).

Clinical presentation



Most patients who contract scabies develop symptoms 3-6 weeks after the initial infestation.  In patients who have previously had scabies (and therefore have prior sensitization), symptoms may begin within 1-3 days of infestation.



Classic scabies is associated with a mild mite burden (10-15 mites).  Patients usually develop several small intensely pruritic erythematous papules, occasionally with crusting.  The pruritus is worse at night and is out of proportion with what is seen on examination.  Vesicles, pustules, or wheals may also develop.  These lesions have a few classic distributions (

figure 1
), including:



  • Upper extremities, particularly involving the interdigital web spaces, sides of the fingers, palms, flexor wrist surfaces, and extensor surfaces of the elbows

  • Abdomen, including the umbilicus and waistline

  • Genitalia

  • Feet

  • Infants frequently have diffuse skin involvement, including the scalp and trunk, and the only manifestation of pruritus is irritability



The presence of burrows (<1-cm thin, serpiginous red tracks on the skin caused by female mites burrowing into the epidermis to lay eggs) are pathognomonic but are often obscured by excoriation.



Elderly patients or those with impaired cell-mediated immunity (eg, HIV, lymphoma) are often unable to contain the scabies infection and develop crusted scabies, which is associated with thousands to millions of mites.  These patients often have mild pruritus (because their inflammatory response is muted) and several plaques with scaling and crusting (

image 2
) (crusted scabies); areas along the scalp, including the ears (
image 3
), are particularly susceptible.

Differential diagnosis



Classic scabies can have features similar to those associated with other disorders involving pruritus, including:



  • Atopic dermatitis:  may have diffuse pruritus similar to scabies; however, atopic dermatitis does not typically present with vesicles and/or pustules involving the palms and soles.

  • Contact dermatitis:  typically localized to a single exposed skin region (compared to scabies, which is spread out), and the area of erythema or vesicles have distinct margins (

    image 4
    ) corresponding to the site of contact.

  • Primary varicella-zoster virus infection (chickenpox):  can present with a pruritic vesicular rash.  Unlike scabies, chickenpox presents with a prodrome of fever and malaise, and lesions typically crust over and resolve within 1-2 weeks.

  • Bedbug infestation:  presents as pruritic, erythematous papules.  However, these papules are often present in linear patterns (

    image 5
    ) ("breakfast, lunch, and dinner" bites); pustules and finger web involvement are not typical.

Diagnostic evaluation



The diagnosis of scabies is usually clinical and is based on medical history and physical examination consistent with the disorder, particularly:



  • Intense pruritus that is worse at night and is out of proportion with what is seen on examination

  • Characteristic lesions (eg, erythematous papules, serpiginous burrows) in a classic distribution (eg, webs and sides of fingers, wrists)

  • Cohabitants with similar symptoms



When the diagnosis is uncertain, examination of skin scrapings with a potassium hydroxide preparation (to remove keratotic debris) can confirm scabies if mites, ova, and feces are observed under light microscopy (

image 6
).

Management



The primary goals of scabies management are as follows:



  • Eradication of the mites with either a topical or oral scabicidal agent



    • Topical permethrin cream blocks mite neurotransmission by impairing voltage-gated sodium channels.  The cream is applied to the entire body from the neck to the soles of the feet, including under the nails.  The cream should also be applied to the face and scalp of children.  The cream is washed off after 8-14 hours.

    • Oral ivermectin, an antiparasitic agent that binds chloride ion channels in invertebrate nerve and muscle cells, can also be used.  Patients are given an initial dose and a second dose after 1-2 weeks.  Ivermectin should be avoided during pregnancy and in infants.

    • Patients with crusted scabies require a combination of permethrin cream and oral ivermectin.

  • Management of complications by providing symptomatic relief (antihistamines for pruritus) and treating secondary bacterial infections (a complication due to repeated scratching) with topical or systemic antibiotics

  • Prevention of transmission with measures to reduce fomite transmission, such as washing bedding, clothing, and personal items in hot water.  Another option is to remove these items from skin contact for 72 hours (because scabies cannot survive more than 3 days away from skin).



Patients may return to school or work the day after the first treatment.  Due to the lengthy incubation period (3-6 weeks), individuals who have had prolonged skin-to-skin contact with the patient in the 6 weeks preceding diagnosis should be treated, even if asymptomatic.  This avoids a cycle of transmission and reinfestation among close contacts.

Prognosis



With successful treatment, skin lesions and nocturnal pruritus should resolve within a week after treatment.  Mild pruritus may persist for up to 4 weeks.  Those whose symptoms worsen despite treatment need to be considered for reexposure or a different diagnosis.
